q: "not committed" to supporting Barack Obama or a specific Republican candidate in 2012. Colin Powell , a retired Army general, said he won't decide whom to vote for until he sees all the candidates. Right now I do not see on the Republican side any one individual who I think is going to emerge at the top of the pile, he said, adding he thinks Barack Obama "is doing a good job right now." not speak for the entire continent. "Ironically, my comment was unintentional," Donald Rumsfeld writes. "I had meant to say France and Germany represented "old NATO' not` old Europe'." In any event, the phrase` old Europe' entered the vernacular. The segments of Americans that preferred calling french fries` freedom fries" loved it, he writes. "The elites in Paris and Bonn who thought themselves the guardians of a sophisticated, new world order did not. All in all I was amused by the ruckus."

offerings. Stephen Elop , a defector from Redmond, and Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer jointly released a statement on the rebel alliance against the growing Android presence in the smart phone market. The statement read: Nokia will adopt Windows Phone as its primary smartphone strategy, innovating on top of the platform in areas such as imaging, where Nokia is a market leader. Stephen Elop implied, in a separate interview, that together Microsoft and Nokia would be able to level the playing field with the exponentially growing Android contingent, as well as high-end smart phone leaders Apple.
